sen.j: 髭切（ひげきり）とは、平安時代に源満仲が作らせたとされる刀で、膝丸とともに源氏重代の刀として伝えられている。
sen.e: "Higekiri" is a sword which MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka is said to have had make in the Heian Period, handed down as a sword of successive generations of the Mianmoto clan as well as Hizamaru.
sen.cmt: 今回の他の記事の用語に合わせ、平安時代→Heian eraは、Heian Periodに。源氏重代の刀→sword of successive generations of Genjiは用語集に合わせsword of successive generations of the Mianmoto clanに。
sen.e: "Higekiri" is a sword which MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka is said to have had made in the Heian Period, handed down, together with another sword, Hizamaru, through successive generations of the Minamoto Clan.
Higekiri is a sword which MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka is said to have had made in the Heian period, handed down, together with another sword, Hizamaru, through successive generations of the Minamoto clan.

sen.j: 平家物語・剣巻では、刀工は「筑前国三笠郡の出山というところに住む唐国の鉄細工」とされているが詳しいことは不明。
sen.e: Tsurugi no maki (chapter named "Tsurugi (sword)") of the Tales of the Heike says that the swordsmith was 'a craftsman of iron from Tang living in a place called Deyama in Mikasa Gori, Chikuzen Province,' but the full details are unknown.
sen.cmt: 平家物語は、Heike Monogatari (The Tales of the Taira family)から、書籍名として定訳となっていると思われるThe Tales of the Heikeに変更。筑前国三笠郡→Mikasa no Kori, Chikuzen Provinceは、http://www.town.nagasu.kumamoto.jp/ContentsView.php?Cd=040420070306105040&Level=3を根拠に、Mikasa Gori, Chikuzen Provinceに変更。出山→Deyama (出山)[定訳不明,該当する地名が見つからず、仮訳です。]鉄細工→craftman of iron facon を、craftsman of ironに変更。
sen.e: The chapter entitled "Tsurugi", or Swords, in the Tales of the Heike says that the swordsmith was 'a craftsman of iron from Tang (China) living in a place called Deyama in Mikasa Gori, Chikuzen Province,' but the full details are unknown.

In Tsurugi no maki (chapter named "Tsurugi" (sword)) of Heike Monogatari (The Tales of the Taira family), it says that the swordsmith was 'a craftsman of iron from Tang (China) living in a place called Deyama in Mikasa Gori, Chikuzen Province,' but the full details are unknown.

sen.j: 罪人を試し切りした際、髭まで切れたというのがこの名の由来である。
sen.e: This name comes from a story that it cut even hige (beard or whisker) when it was tried out on a criminal.
The name, which means 'beard cutter', comes from a story that when it was tried out on a criminal, it passed right through the neck and cut off his beard.

sen.j: 源頼光の代、配下の渡辺綱が一条戻橋で鬼の腕を切ったとされ、その際名を鬼切と改めた。
sen.e: It is said that, during the possession of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, his follower WATANABE no Tsuna cut an arm of an Oni (ogre) on the Ichijomodori-bashi Bridge, when its name was changed to Onikiri (literally, "cutting oni").

When the sword had passed to MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, it is said to have been used by his retainer, WATANABE no Tsuna, to cut off the arm of an Oni (ogre) on the Ichijomodori-bashi Bridge, and its name was changed to Onikiri (Oni Cutter).

When the sword had passed to MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, it is said to have been used by his retainer, WATANABE no Tsuna, to cut off the arm of an Oni (ogre) on the Ichijomodori-bashi Bridge, and its name was changed to Onikiri (Oni Cutter).

sen.j: その後もこの刀は次々と名を変えることになる。
sen.e: After this incident, this sword changed its name one after another.
After this incident, the sword's name was repeatedly changed.

sen.j: 源為義の代には夜に獅子の鳴くような声で吠えたので獅子ノ子と名を改めた。
sen.e: During the possession of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi, it roared at night like a shishi lion did, when its name was changed to Shishinoko.
While in the possession of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi, it roared at night like a shishi lion and its name was changed to Shishinoko (Lion's Child).

sen.e: While in the possession of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi, it roared at night like a shishi lion and its name was changed to Shishinoko (Lion's Child).

sen.j: また源為義が兄弟刀の吠丸（膝丸）を娘婿である熊野別当教真に譲った際、吠丸の代刀として作られた小烏が当初は獅子の子より二分ほど長かった。
sen.e: When MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi gave Hoemaru (Hizamaru), its kyodaigatana (a sword made by the same person) to his son-in-law, Kyoshin, the chief priest of the Kumano shrines, Kogarasu, made as the alternative sword was about 6mm shorter than Shishinoko initially.
sen.cmt: 熊野別当教真→Kyoshin, steward, KUMANOとありましたが、Kyoshin, the chief priest of the Kumano shrinesにしました。（http://www.kumadoco.net/dictionary/report.php?no=168)
sen.e: When MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi gave Hoemaru (also called Hizamaru), Shishinoko's kyodaigatana (a sword made by the same person), to his son-in-law, Kyoshin, the chief priest of the Kumano shrines, Kogarasu, made as a replacement for Hoemaru, was originally about 6mm shorter than Shishinoko.

When MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi gave Hoemaru (also called Hizamaru), Shishinoko's kyodaigatana (a sword made by the same person), to his son-in-law, Kyoshin, the chief priest of the Kumano-jinja Shrines, Kogarasu, made as a replacement for Hoemaru, was originally about 6 mm shorter than Shishinoko.

sen.j: しかしあるとき二本を抜いて障子に寄り掛けていたとき、人も触れないのに二本が倒れ、二本が同じ長さになっているのを見て不審に思った教真が調べてみると小烏の目貫が二分ほど切られていた。
sen.e: But one day, drawn and placed against Shoji (paper sliding door), the two swords fell without being touched, and Kyoshin noticed that they were the same length, wondered why and examined, and then he found that the menuki (sword handle ornaments) of Kogarasu was cut for about 6mm.
sen.cmt: 障子→Shoji (a generic term for partitions, that may slide, hang or remain stationary, that can divide the interior of a building into separate rooms)は長過ぎるので、Shoji (paper sliding door)にしました。目貫→menuki (pairs of small metal ornaments, secured one to each side of the hilt of the sword by means of a braid that covers the hilt)は、menuki (sword handle ornaments)にしました。
sen.e: But one day, the two swords, unsheathed and placed against a shoji sliding paper door, fell without being touched, and Kyoshin, wondering why they were now the same length, examined them and found that the menuki (sword handle ornaments) of Kogarasu had been cut by about 6mm.

sen.cmt: スペースを補足しました。

sen.j: それを獅子の子の仕業と考え名を友切と改めた。
sen.e: He thought it was done by Shishinoko, and renamed it Tomogiri (literally "cutting a friend").
Believing this had been done by Shishinoko, he renamed it Tomogiri (literally "friend cutter").

sen.j: その後源義朝の代になり、源氏重代の刀である友切を持っているのにも関わらず敗戦続きなのを八幡大菩薩に恨み、「世の末になって剣の力も失せたのか」と嘆いていた。
sen.e: And in the possession of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo, although possessing Tomogiri, the sword of successive generations of the Mianmoto clan, he kept loosing battles and blamed this on Hachiman (God of War) Great Bodhisattva, and mourned, 'the power of the sword must disappear in the end of the world', then Great Bodhisattva gave him revelation, saying 'It is due to the name Tomogiri.

sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo, although possessing Tomogiri, the sword inherited by generations of the Minamoto Clan, kept losing battles and, blaming it on Hachiman, the God of War (and guardian of the clan), mourned, 'will the sword's power still be missing at the end of the world,' at which Hachiman appeared to him, saying, 'it is due to the name Tomogiri.

sen.j: 尚、兄弟刀の膝丸は源義経に伝えられ、源義経が討たれた後に源頼朝のもとに渡ったという。
sen.e: It is said that Hizamaru, the kyodaigatana was handed down to MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune, and then handed down to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo after MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune was defeated and died.
